**Quicken Loans Arena** , commonly[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] known
as "**The Q** ", is a multi-purpose [arena](/wiki/Arena "Arena") in [downtown
Cleveland](/wiki/Downtown_Cleveland "Downtown Cleveland"), [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio
"Ohio"), United States. The building is the home of the [Cleveland
Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") of the [National
Basketball Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National
Basketball Association") (NBA), the [Cleveland
Monsters](/wiki/Cleveland_Monsters "Cleveland Monsters") of the [American
Hockey League](/wiki/American_Hockey_League "American Hockey League"), and the
[Cleveland Gladiators](/wiki/Cleveland_Gladiators "Cleveland Gladiators") of
the [Arena Football League](/wiki/Arena_Football_League "Arena Football
League"). It also serves as a secondary arena for [Cleveland State
Vikings](/wiki/Cleveland_State_Vikings "Cleveland State Vikings") men's and
women's basketball.

The arena opened in October 1994 as part of the [Gateway Sports and
Entertainment Complex](/wiki/Gateway_Sports_and_Entertainment_Complex "Gateway
Sports and Entertainment Complex") with adjacent [Progressive
Field](/wiki/Progressive_Field "Progressive Field"), which opened in April of
that year. It is named for the retail mortgage lender [Quicken
Loans](/wiki/Quicken_Loans "Quicken Loans"), whose chairman and founder is
[Dan Gilbert](/wiki/Dan_Gilbert_\(businessman\) "Dan Gilbert
\(businessman\)"), the majority owner of the Cavaliers, Monsters, and
Gladiators. From its opening until August 2005, it was known as **Gund Arena**
, named for former Cavaliers owner [Gordon Gund](/wiki/Gordon_Gund "Gordon
Gund"), after he paid for the [naming rights](/wiki/Naming_rights "Naming
rights"). The Q replaced the [Richfield Coliseum](/wiki/Coliseum_at_Richfield
"Coliseum at Richfield") as the primary entertainment facility for the region
and the home of the Cavaliers, and supplanted the [Wolstein
Center](/wiki/Wolstein_Center "Wolstein Center") at [Cleveland State
University](/wiki/Cleveland_State_University "Cleveland State University"),
which opened in 1990, as the primary concert and athletic venue in downtown
Cleveland.

Quicken Loans Arena seats 20,562 people in its basketball configuration and up
to 20,056 for ice hockey, making it the second-largest [arena in the
NBA](/wiki/List_of_National_Basketball_Association_arenas "List of National
Basketball Association arenas") by [seating capacity](/wiki/Seating_capacity
"Seating capacity"). It is a frequent site for concerts and other athletic
events such as the [men's](/wiki/Mid-
American_Conference_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "Mid-American Conference
Men's Basketball Tournament") and [women's](/wiki/Mid-
American_Conference_Women%27s_Basketball_Tournament "Mid-American Conference
Women's Basketball Tournament") basketball tournaments of the [Mid-American
Conference](/wiki/Mid-American_Conference "Mid-American Conference") (MAC),
hosting the men's tournament since 2000 and the women's tournament since 2001.
It has also been the host venue for the [2007 NCAA Women's Division I
Basketball Final
Four](/wiki/2007_NCAA_Women%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament "2007 NCAA
Women's Division I Basketball Tournament"), opening and regional semifinal
games in the [NCAA Division I Men's Basketball
Tournament](/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament "NCAA Men's
Division I Basketball Tournament"), and the [U.S. Figure Skating
Championships](/wiki/U.S._Figure_Skating_Championships "U.S. Figure Skating
Championships") in [2000](/wiki/2000_U.S._Figure_Skating_Championships "2000
U.S. Figure Skating Championships") and
[2009](/wiki/2009_U.S._Figure_Skating_Championships "2009 U.S. Figure Skating
Championships"). In July 2016, The Q hosted the [2016 Republican National
Convention](/wiki/2016_Republican_National_Convention "2016 Republican
National Convention").

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quicken_Loans_Arena&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/33/Gund_Arena.svg/100px-
Gund_Arena.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Gund_Arena.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Gund_Arena.svg "Enlarge")

The arena logo from 1994 to 2005.

The Q was preceded in downtown Cleveland by the [Cleveland
Arena](/wiki/Cleveland_Arena "Cleveland Arena"), a facility built in 1937 with
a [seating capacity](/wiki/Seating_capacity "Seating capacity") for basketball
of approximately 12,000. It was best known as the site of the [Moondog
Coronation Ball](/wiki/Moondog_Coronation_Ball "Moondog Coronation Ball") in
1952, widely regarded as the first [rock and roll](/wiki/Rock_and_roll "Rock
and roll") concert.[6] Cleveland Arena was the first home of the Cavaliers in
1970.[6]

The Cleveland Arena was also the home of an earlier professional basketball
team, the [Cleveland Rebels](/wiki/Cleveland_Rebels "Cleveland Rebels") of the
[Basketball Association of America](/wiki/Basketball_Association_of_America
"Basketball Association of America"), the original [Cleveland
Barons](/wiki/Cleveland_Barons_\(1937%E2%80%9373\) "Cleveland Barons
\(1937–73\)") ice hockey team, and hosted several games of the [Cincinnati
Royals](/wiki/Cincinnati_Royals "Cincinnati Royals") of the NBA in the 1960s.
By 1970, however, Cleveland Arena was outdated and in disrepair. The Cavs
played there their first four seasons. It was replaced in 1974 by the
20,273-seat [Richfield Coliseum](/wiki/Richfield_Coliseum "Richfield
Coliseum"), located in [Richfield](/wiki/Richfield,_Ohio "Richfield, Ohio"),
between Cleveland and [Akron](/wiki/Akron,_Ohio "Akron, Ohio").[6]

During the 1980s, the site of the Central Market, a fruit and vegetable market
that dated back to 1856, was selected for construction of a multi-purpose
domed stadium for the [Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland
Browns") and [Cleveland Indians](/wiki/Cleveland_Indians "Cleveland Indians"),
but the ballot measure to fund it was defeated by voters. The market site was
acquired in 1985 and cleared in 1987 in a continued push for new downtown
sports facilities by city and business leaders. In 1990, voters approved a
[sin tax](/wiki/Sin_tax "Sin tax") on alcohol and tobacco products in Cuyahoga
County to fund the [Gateway Sports and Entertainment
Complex](/wiki/Gateway_Sports_and_Entertainment_Complex "Gateway Sports and
Entertainment Complex"), which includes the Q and adjacent [Progressive
Field](/wiki/Progressive_Field "Progressive Field").[7] Construction began in
1992 with the ballpark opening in April 1994 and the arena in October
1994.[8][9] The arena opened with a concert by [Billy Joel](/wiki/Billy_Joel
"Billy Joel") on October 17, 1994. The Cavaliers played their first regular-
season game in the arena a few weeks later, a loss to the [Houston
Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston Rockets"), on November 8, 1994.[10]

As part of his purchase of the team and the arena naming rights in 2005, [Dan
Gilbert](/wiki/Dan_Gilbert_\(businessman\) "Dan Gilbert \(businessman\)"),
owner of [Quicken Loans](/wiki/Quicken_Loans "Quicken Loans"), funded
renovations of the arena, which included installing new wine-colored seats,
state-of-the-art [scoreboards](/wiki/Scoreboard "Scoreboard"), video systems,
and sound systems, new arena graphics and signage, and upgrades to security,
locker rooms, and the suites, all of which were in place for the start of the
Cavaliers [2005–2006 season](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_Cleveland_Cavaliers_season
"2005–06 Cleveland Cavaliers season"), except for the seats, which were
replaced a few sections at a time.

Gilbert purchased the then-inactive [Utah
Grizzlies](/wiki/Utah_Grizzlies_\(1995%E2%80%932005\) "Utah Grizzlies
\(1995–2005\)") franchise of the [American Hockey
League](/wiki/American_Hockey_League "American Hockey League") on May 16,
2006, and announced that it would move to Quicken Loans Arena to replace the
departed [Cleveland Barons](/wiki/Cleveland_Barons_\(2001%E2%80%9306\)
"Cleveland Barons \(2001–06\)"). The team name was announced as the Lake Erie
Monsters on January 25, 2007, and began play in the 2007–08 season. The Lake
Erie Monsters changed their name to the [Cleveland
Monsters](/wiki/Cleveland_Monsters "Cleveland Monsters") on August 9, 2016.

The [Las Vegas Gladiators](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Gladiators "Las Vegas Gladiators")
of the [Arena Football League](/wiki/Arena_Football_League "Arena Football
League") announced on October 16, 2007, that they would move to Quicken Loans
Arena, becoming the [Cleveland Gladiators](/wiki/Cleveland_Gladiators
"Cleveland Gladiators").

Plans for a two-year, $140 million renovation project to begin in 2017 were
released by the Cavaliers in December 2016. The project calls for an increase
in the square footage of the concourses and open areas, along with upgrades
throughout the building. It is scheduled to be completed by late 2019.[11]

### Design and
operations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quicken_Loans_Arena&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Design and operations")]

The arena seats 20,562 for basketball, with 2,000 club seats and 88 [luxury
suites](/wiki/Luxury_suite "Luxury suite"). Seating is divided into three
levels, with two main levels of suites and five "platinum suites" on the event
level. Around the seating there are two main concourses, one on the ground
level to access the 100 level seating and 32 lower suites, and an upper
concourse for the top 200 level seating. The lower concourse also includes the
ticket office and the two-level main team shop. In between is the club level,
which provides access to the 60 upper suites and club seating. Also on the
club level is an auxiliary gym, which was used by the Cavaliers as their main
practice court until the opening of the Cleveland Clinic Courts practice
facility in 2007.

In the hockey and arena football configuration, capacity is 20,056. During
most Monsters games, the upper-level seating is closed and covered by a large
curtain, reducing capacity to 10,025. In the basketball configuration, when
the upper level seating is closed, capacity is listed at 11,751. 60% of the
seating is located in the lower two levels.[12]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Humongotron.jpg/300px-
Humongotron.jpg)](/wiki/File:Humongotron.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Humongotron.jpg "Enlarge")

The scoreboard with flames during player introductions in 2014

The main scoreboard at The Q, nicknamed _Humongotron_ , is the second largest
scoreboard used in an NBA arena. It was installed in October 2014 after Cavs
owner Dan Gilbert had seen a similar scoreboard at the [Toyota
Center](/wiki/Toyota_Center "Toyota Center") in Houston during the [2013 NBA
All-Star Weekend](/wiki/2013_NBA_All-Star_Game "2013 NBA All-Star Game"). The
scoreboard includes four large [high-definition video](/wiki/High-
definition_video "High-definition video") screens with large
[sabers](/wiki/Sabers "Sabers") on each corner that can extend outward to
shoot fire, usually as part of player introductions. The two screens facing
the sidelines are 31.5 feet (9.6 m) high and 56.69 feet (17.28 m) wide, while
the two screens facing the baselines measure 29.92 feet (9.12 m) high and
33.07 feet (10.08 m) wide.[12][13][14]

On the roof of the building is a large LED message board that measures 360
feet (110 m) by 90 feet (27 m), described as the "largest LED roof sign on the
planet" by Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert. The sign was approved by the Cleveland
City Planning Commission in March 2016 with the stipulation that only the
arena's name or its naming rights sponsor can be shown. Any other use of the
sign needs commission approval. The message board was installed later in 2016
and debuted in May during Game 1 of the [Eastern Conference
finals](/wiki/2016_NBA_Playoffs#Conference_Finals:_\(1\)_Cleveland_Cavaliers_vs._\(2\)_Toronto_Raptors
"2016 NBA Playoffs").[15][16]

The arena, along with neighboring Progressive Field and an adjacent parking
garage, is owned by the Gateway Economic Development Corporation of Greater
Cleveland, an entity made up of members appointed by the governments of the
city of Cleveland and [Cuyahoga County](/wiki/Cuyahoga_County,_Ohio "Cuyahoga
County, Ohio"). Gateway leases the arena to the Cavaliers, who also manage the
[Cleveland Monsters](/wiki/Cleveland_Monsters "Cleveland Monsters") and the
[Cleveland Gladiators](/wiki/Cleveland_Gladiators "Cleveland Gladiators").[17]
Food service is managed by [Aramark](/wiki/Aramark "Aramark") and includes
items contributed by award-winning chef [Michael Symon](/wiki/Michael_Symon
"Michael Symon"). Two existing restaurants were renamed in 2009 after Symon's
bar-bistros "Bar Symon" and "The B-Spot", and some of his signature dishes are
available as suite catering offerings.[18]

In March 2017, in partnership with the non-profit organization KultureCity,
Quicken Loans Arena officially introduced the availability of
[accommodations](/wiki/Autism_friendly "Autism friendly") during all events
for guests with hypersensitivity needs, such as attendees with [autism
spectrum](/wiki/Autism_spectrum "Autism spectrum") disorders. This includes
staff training, free "sensory bags" with headphones, a blanket, and other
items geared towards attendees with sensory needs, as well as a [sensory
room](/wiki/Sensory_room "Sensory room") and exemptions from re-entry policies
if they are overwhelmed by the environment. The arena became the first in the
NBA to be certified by KultureCity as being "sensory inclusive".[19][20]

## Tenants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quicken_Loans_Arena&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Tenants")]

###
Current[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quicken_Loans_Arena&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Current")]

As home of the Cavaliers, Monsters, and Gladiators, The Q has hosted a number
of notable events for each team, including playoff and championship games.
Through the 2015–16 season, the Cavs have hosted playoff games in 10 of their
22 seasons at The Q, including games three and four of the [2007 NBA
Finals](/wiki/2007_NBA_Finals "2007 NBA Finals"), and games three, four, and
six of the [2015](/wiki/2015_NBA_Finals "2015 NBA Finals") and [2016
Finals](/wiki/2016_NBA_Finals "2016 NBA Finals"). The arena was also the site
of the [1997 NBA All-Star Game](/wiki/1997_NBA_All-Star_Game "1997 NBA All-
Star Game"), which celebrated the 50th anniversary of the founding of the NBA.

The Gladiators have qualified for the [Arena Football
League](/wiki/Arena_Football_League "Arena Football League") playoffs in four
of their seven seasons in Cleveland through 2015, and hosted playoff games in
2008, 2011, and 2014. During the 2014 season, the team finished 15–1 overall
and advanced to [ArenaBowl XXVII](/wiki/ArenaBowl_XXVII "ArenaBowl XXVII"),
which hosted at Quicken Loans Arena. The game drew 18,410 fans and was held at
the same time as a [Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland
Browns") home preseason game at [FirstEnergy
Stadium](/wiki/FirstEnergy_Stadium_\(Cleveland\) "FirstEnergy Stadium
\(Cleveland\)"), and a [Cleveland Indians](/wiki/Cleveland_Indians "Cleveland
Indians") home game at adjacent [Progressive Field](/wiki/Progressive_Field
"Progressive Field").[21][22]

The Monsters made their playoff debut in 2011 and returned to the playoffs in
2016. In the [2016 Calder Cup playoffs](/wiki/2016_Calder_Cup_playoffs "2016
Calder Cup playoffs"), the team advanced to the [Calder Cup](/wiki/Calder_Cup
"Calder Cup") final and swept the [Hershey Bears](/wiki/Hershey_Bears "Hershey
Bears") in four games for their first Calder Cup in franchise history. Games
three and four were held at The Q. Game four, held on June 11, was a sell-out
and drew 19,665 fans, which set a record for largest crowd to ever see a
professional hockey game in the state of Ohio and the second-largest
postseason crowd in [American Hockey League](/wiki/American_Hockey_League
"American Hockey League") history.[23]

### Former[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quicken_Loans_Arena&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Former")]

Quicken Loans Arena has been home to other franchises that have either
relocated or folded. When it opened in 1994, in addition to being home of the
Cavaliers, it was also the home arena for the [Cleveland
Lumberjacks](/wiki/Cleveland_Lumberjacks "Cleveland Lumberjacks") of the
[International Hockey
League](/wiki/International_Hockey_League_\(1945%E2%80%932001\) "International
Hockey League \(1945–2001\)") (IHL). The Lumberjacks played at the arena until
2001 when the team folded along with the IHL. Later that year a new
incarnation of the [Cleveland Barons](/wiki/Cleveland_Barons_\(2001-2006\)
"Cleveland Barons \(2001-2006\)"), who played in the American Hockey League,
began play and were tenants at the arena until 2006 when the team moved to
[Worcester, Massachusetts](/wiki/Worcester,_Massachusetts "Worcester,
Massachusetts").

Two women's professional teams have also called the arena home. From 1997 to
2003, the [Cleveland Rockers](/wiki/Cleveland_Rockers "Cleveland Rockers"),
one of the eight charter members of the [Women's National Basketball
Association](/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association "Women's National
Basketball Association") (WNBA), played at The Q. The team folded after the
[2003 WNBA season](/wiki/2003_WNBA_season "2003 WNBA season") because the
Gunds, who still owned the Cavs at that point, no longer wished to operate the
Rockers franchise and a new ownership group could not be obtained. The
[Cleveland Crush](/wiki/Toledo_Crush "Toledo Crush") of the [Lingerie Football
League](/wiki/Legends_Football_League "Legends Football League") played at The
Q for their 2011–12 and 2012–13 seasons before moving to [Toledo,
Ohio](/wiki/Toledo,_Ohio "Toledo, Ohio"), in late 2013.[24]

## Events[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quicken_Loans_Arena&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Events")]

### College
Sports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quicken_Loans_Arena&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: College Sports")]

In addition to its professional sports tenants, The Q has hosted a number of
intercollegiate sporting events. It has been home to the [Mid-American
Conference](/wiki/Mid-American_Conference "Mid-American Conference") (MAC)
[Men's Basketball Tournament](/wiki/Mid-
American_Conference_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "Mid-American Conference
Men's Basketball Tournament") since 2000 and the MAC [MAC Women's Basketball
Tournament](/wiki/Mid-American_Conference_Women%27s_Basketball_Tournament
"Mid-American Conference Women's Basketball Tournament") since 2001. "MAC
Madness", as it is known, has become a strong draw for the arena. The men's
semifinal and championship games routinely draw 10,000-15,000 attendees. In
addition, Quicken Loans Arena has served as a host for games of the [NCAA
Men's Division I Basketball
Championship](/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Championship "NCAA
Men's Division I Basketball Championship"), hosting early round games in
[2011](/wiki/2011_NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament "2011 NCAA
Men's Division I Basketball Tournament") and regional semifinal and final
games in [2015](/wiki/2015_NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament "2015
NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament").[25] The Q has also hosted games
for the [NCAA Women's Division I Basketball
Championship](/wiki/NCAA_Women%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Championship "NCAA
Women's Division I Basketball Championship"), hosting regional semifinals and
finals for the [2006
tournament](/wiki/2006_NCAA_Women%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament "2006
NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Tournament") and the Final Four and
national championship game of the [2007
tournament](/wiki/2007_NCAA_Women%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament "2007
NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Tournament").

In 2015, it was announced that arena management and [Cleveland State
University](/wiki/Cleveland_State_University "Cleveland State University")
came to an agreement where select [CSU Vikings](/wiki/CSU_Vikings "CSU
Vikings") men's and women's basketball games would take place at The Q, while
Quicken Loans Arena would essentially take over operations of the [Wolstein
Center](/wiki/Wolstein_Center "Wolstein Center") (CSU's primary home arena),
being in charge of promoting and booking events at the venue.[26]

### Other
events[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quicken_Loans_Arena&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Other events")]

In addition to team sports, The Q has hosted a number of other events,
including the [2000](/wiki/2000_U.S._Figure_Skating_Championships "2000 U.S.
Figure Skating Championships") and [2009 U.S. Figure Skating
Championships](/wiki/2009_U.S._Figure_Skating_Championships "2009 U.S. Figure
Skating Championships") along with professional wrestling broadcasts for
_[Raw](/wiki/WWE_RAW "WWE RAW")_ and _[SmackDown](/wiki/WWE_SmackDown "WWE
SmackDown")_ , and numerous [WWE](/wiki/WWE "WWE") pay–per–view events:

  * [SummerSlam (1996)](/wiki/SummerSlam_\(1996\) "SummerSlam \(1996\)") \- headlined by [Shawn Michaels](/wiki/Shawn_Michaels "Shawn Michaels") vs. [Vader](/wiki/Big_Van_Vader "Big Van Vader") for the [WWF Championship](/wiki/WWF_Championship "WWF Championship")
  * [No Mercy (1999)](/wiki/No_Mercy_\(1999\) "No Mercy \(1999\)") \- headlined by [Triple H](/wiki/Triple_H "Triple H") vs. [Stone Cold Steve Austin](/wiki/Stone_Cold_Steve_Austin "Stone Cold Steve Austin") for the [WWF Championship](/wiki/WWF_Championship "WWF Championship")
  * [Invasion](/wiki/WWF_Invasion "WWF Invasion") (2001) - headlined by Team Alliance vs. Team WWF.
  * [Survivor Series (2004)](/wiki/Survivor_Series_\(2004\) "Survivor Series \(2004\)") \- headlined by Team [Orton](/wiki/Randy_Orton "Randy Orton") vs. Team [Triple H](/wiki/Triple_H "Triple H")
  * [Unforgiven (2008)](/wiki/Unforgiven_\(2008\) "Unforgiven \(2008\)") \- headlined by the first ever [Championship Scramble](/wiki/Professional_wrestling_match_types "Professional wrestling match types") matches.
  * [TLC: Tables, Ladders and Chairs (2014)](/wiki/TLC:_Tables,_Ladders_and_Chairs_\(2014\) "TLC: Tables, Ladders and Chairs \(2014\)") \- headlined by Bray Wyatt vs. Dean Ambrose in a [TLC](/wiki/Tables,_Ladders,_and_Chairs_match "Tables, Ladders, and Chairs match") match.
  * [Fastlane (2016)](/wiki/Fastlane_\(2016\) "Fastlane \(2016\)") \- headlined by [Brock Lesnar](/wiki/Brock_Lesnar "Brock Lesnar") vs. [Roman Reigns](/wiki/Roman_Reigns "Roman Reigns") vs. [Dean Ambrose](/wiki/Dean_Ambrose "Dean Ambrose") in a Triple Threat match for the #1 contender for the [WWE World Heavyweight Championship](/wiki/WWE_World_Heavyweight_Championship "WWE World Heavyweight Championship") at [WrestleMania 32](/wiki/WrestleMania_32 "WrestleMania 32").

[LeBron James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James") gathered almost 20,000
people at the arena on October 29, 2008, for a viewing of Democratic
presidential nominee [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama")'s
30-minute _[American Stories, American
Solutions](/wiki/American_Stories,_American_Solutions "American Stories,
American Solutions")_ television advertisement. It was shown on a large screen
above the stage, where [Jay-Z](/wiki/Jay-Z "Jay-Z") later held a free
concert.[27]

Quicken Loans Arena was selected in July 2014 as the host site for the [2016
Republican National Convention](/wiki/2016_Republican_National_Convention
"2016 Republican National Convention"). The arena hosted the first Republican
presidential debate of the 2016 election, aired by [Fox News
Channel](/wiki/Fox_News_Channel "Fox News Channel"), on August 6, 2015. The
convention was held July 18–21, 2016.[28]

Cleveland-area native [Stipe Miocic](/wiki/Stipe_Miocic "Stipe Miocic")
defended his heavyweight championship at [UFC 203](/wiki/UFC_203 "UFC 203"),
which was held at The Q on September 10, 2016.
